title: 108_s1633
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft Notification and Credit Restoration Act of 2003". Congress finds that the privacy and financial security of individuals are increasingly at risk due to the widespread collection of personal information. Credit card transactions, real estate records, consumer surveys, credit reports, and Internet websites are all sources of personal information for identity thieves. Identity theft is a fast-growing crime in the United States, posing a major law enforcement challenge. Criminals use stolen personal information for fraudulent activities, leading to financial crimes. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported identity theft to the Federal Trade Commission. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported identity theft to the Federal Trade Commission, which is more than three times the number reported in 2000. Identity theft is costly to consumers and the United States marketplace. Victims of identity theft often have to contact multiple law enforcement agencies, credit reporting agencies, and creditors over many years. The government, financial institutions, and credit reporting agencies have a shared responsibility to protect consumer information from identity thieves and assist victims. The private sector can enhance consumer protection by improving customer notification and implementing effective fraud alerts. The private sector can enhance consumer protection by improving customer notification, implementing effective fraud alerts, affording greater consumer access to credit reports, and establishing other financial identity theft prevention measures. SEC. 3. TIMELY NOTIFICATION OF UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS TO PERSONAL INFORMATION. This section amends the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act to include notification to customers of unauthorized access to personal information. In this section, a breach is defined as the unauthorized acquisition of data compromising the security of personal information held by a financial institution. Personal information for a customer includes their first name or initial, last name, and certain data elements like social security number or driver's license number. The breach of personal information at a financial institution requires prompt notification to affected customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement agencies. This includes sensitive data such as social security numbers, driver's license numbers, and financial account access codes. Financial institutions must promptly notify affected customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement of any breach involving personal information. Other entities holding customer data for financial institutions must also report breaches. Notification must be made without delay upon discovery of the breach, considering law enforcement needs and scope determination measures. Financial institutions must promptly notify affected customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement of any breach involving personal information. Notification may be delayed for law enforcement purposes if it would impede a criminal investigation, but must be made promptly once it would not compromise the investigation. Notification can be provided in writing or electronically, following the Electronic Signatures Act. Financial institutions must notify customers of breaches promptly, following the Electronic Signatures Act. Notification can be in writing or electronically, including email or a website posting if other forms are prohibitive or contact information is insufficient. Financial institutions are required to promptly notify customers of breaches through various means such as written notification, electronic notification, website postings, media notifications, or other forms as prescribed by the Federal Trade Commission. Notifications must also be sent to consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement agencies as specified by the FTC. Each notification to a customer must include a statement that credit reporting agencies have been informed of the breach. Financial institutions must notify customers of breaches, including informing credit reporting agencies and placing fraud alerts on customer credit reports. Compliance is achieved by establishing a comprehensive information security program. Financial institutions must notify customers and consumer reporting agencies of breaches in accordance with internal security policies. Customers can seek damages for violations, and institutions may face injunctions for non-compliance. These rights are in addition to other available remedies under the law. Financial institutions must comply with this section without violating any laws prohibiting financial information disclosure. They are not required to disclose information prohibited by law, and no new recordkeeping obligations are created. SEC. 4. INCLUSION OF FRAUD ALERTS IN CONSUMER CREDIT REPORTS. Section 605 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include a definition of fraud alerts, which notify users of a consumer's credit report about potential identity theft and unauthorized credit issuance. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in consumer files, which can be requested by the consumer or added upon notification by a financial institution. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in consumer files. Consumer reporting agencies must inform anyone accessing consumer credit information about the presence of a fraud alert, regardless of the type of report requested. The Federal Trade Commission will establish regulations for the duration and removal of fraud alerts. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include procedures for fraud alerts in consumer files. Violations include failure to notify users of a fraud alert and taking adverse action based solely on a fraud alert. The Fair Credit Reporting Act prohibits taking adverse action against a consumer solely based on a fraud alert in their file. SEC. 5. ACCESS TO CREDIT REPORTS AND SCORES. No Fee in Certain Cases--Consumer reporting agencies must provide free access to credit reports and scores upon consumer request, once per year and every 3 months during a fraud alert period. A reasonable fee may be charged for disclosures related to fraud alerts. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include credit scores in disclosures, as per section 526(b)(1)(B) of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act. The Federal Trade Commission must issue final regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment, in consultation with other financial regulatory agencies.
